title: Ex-Jack Morris, Roush-Powered 1969 Ford Mustang SportsRoof 6-Speed
description: This 1969 Ford Mustang was originally built as a 302-powered SportsRoof, and it was modified as a custom commission for MLB pitcher Jack Morris at a claimed cost of over $400k. The customized body is mounted on a chromoly frame with an integrated roll cage, and it has a Heidts independent front end and a four-link rear end with a Panhard bar as well as coilovers all around. The car rides on staggered modular BBS wheels and has four-wheel disc brakes, and power is from a Roush-built Ford V8 with a Dart aluminum block, Wiseco pistons, Eagle connecting rods, AFR 225 heads, and a Holley carburetor. Claimed to produce over 600 horsepower, it is linked to a six-speed manual transmission and a Ford 9" rear end with an Eaton Truetrac differential and 4.11 gears. Inside are bucket seats, harnesses, custom upholstery, air conditioning, and a Hurst shifter. Following completion of the build, the car was a finalist in the Goodguys Muscle Machine of the Year selection for 2012. Acquired in 2020 by its current owner, a retail Arizona dealer, this modified Mustang is now offered on their behalf with build documents and a clean Arizona title.
author: bringatrailer
excerpt: Bid for the chance to own a Ex-Jack Morris, Roush-Powered 1969 Ford Mustang SportsRoof 6-Speed at auction with Bring a Trailer, the home of the best vintage and classic cars online. Lot #202,201.
text: This 1969 Ford Mustang was originally built as a 302-powered SportsRoof, and it was modified as a custom commission for MLB pitcher Jack Morris at a claimed cost of over $400k. The customized body is mounted on a chromoly frame with an integrated roll cage, and it has a Heidts independent front end and a four-link rear end with a Panhard bar as well as coilovers all around. The car rides on staggered modular BBS wheels and has four-wheel disc brakes, and power is from a Roush-built Ford V8 with a Dart aluminum block, Wiseco pistons, Eagle connecting rods, AFR 225 heads, and a Holley carburetor. Claimed to produce over 600 horsepower, it is linked to a six-speed manual transmission and a Ford 9″ rear end with an Eaton Truetrac differential and 4.11 gears. Inside are bucket seats, harnesses, custom upholstery, air conditioning, and a Hurst shifter. Following completion of the build, the car was a finalist in the Goodguys Muscle Machine of the Year selection for 2012. Acquired in 2020 by its current owner, a retail Arizona dealer, this modified Mustang is now offered on their behalf with build documents and a clean Arizona title. The body panels have been modified and painted Mercedes-Benz silver with House of Kolor Galaxy Gray accents. The body is mounted on a custom chromoly frame with an integrated cage. The car rides on a modified suspension with a Heidt Mustang II-style front end using tubular control arms and rack-and-pinion steering. Out back is a four-link setup with a Panhard bar. Adjustable Ridetech coilovers are fitted all around along with Wilwood six-piston calipers matched with cross-drilled rotors. The BBS modular wheels measure 18″ up front and 19″ out back, and they have 285/35 and 345/30 Michelin tires mounted, respectively. The Sparco seats are matched with Simpson harnesses, and custom leather upholstery was fitted to the cabin along with air conditioning and a Hurst shifter. A Grant GT steering wheel and Auto Meter gauges were also utilized. The cluster indicates 471 miles. The custom Roush V8 uses a Dart aluminum block, Wiseco forged pistons, an Eagle crankshaft and connecting rods, Clevite bearings, a COMP cams solid roller camshaft and lifters, and Trend pushrods along with AFR heads. The Holley HP-series carburetor is mounted on an Edelbrock Super Victor intake manifold. Stainless-steel headers are linked to a custom exhaust system, and the engine has fabricated aluminum valve covers. The engine is claimed to produce over 600 horsepower. The Tremec T56 six-speed manual is linked to a Ford 9″ rear end with a Detroit Truetrac differential and 4.11 gears. You are not connected to real-time updates. Attempting to connect. html:
This 1969 Ford Mustang was originally built as a 302-powered SportsRoof, and it was modified as a custom commission for MLB pitcher Jack Morris at a claimed cost of over $400k. The customized body is mounted on a chromoly frame with an integrated roll cage, and it has a Heidts independent front end and a four-link rear end with a Panhard bar as well as coilovers all around. The car rides on staggered modular BBS wheels and has four-wheel disc brakes, and power is from a Roush-built Ford V8 with a Dart aluminum block, Wiseco pistons, Eagle connecting rods, AFR 225 heads, and a Holley carburetor. Claimed to produce over 600 horsepower, it is linked to a six-speed manual transmission and a Ford 9″ rear end with an Eaton Truetrac differential and 4.11 gears. Inside are bucket seats, harnesses, custom upholstery, air conditioning, and a Hurst shifter. Following completion of the build, the car was a finalist in the Goodguys Muscle Machine of the Year selection for 2012. Acquired in 2020 by its current owner, a retail Arizona dealer, this modified Mustang is now offered on their behalf with build documents and a clean Arizona title.

The body panels have been modified and painted Mercedes-Benz silver with House of Kolor Galaxy Gray accents. The body is mounted on a custom chromoly frame with an integrated cage.

The car rides on a modified suspension with a Heidt Mustang II-style front end using tubular control arms and rack-and-pinion steering. Out back is a four-link setup with a Panhard bar. Adjustable Ridetech coilovers are fitted all around along with Wilwood six-piston calipers matched with cross-drilled rotors.

The BBS modular wheels measure 18″ up front and 19″ out back, and they have 285/35 and 345/30 Michelin tires mounted, respectively.

The Sparco seats are matched with Simpson harnesses, and custom leather upholstery was fitted to the cabin along with air conditioning and a Hurst shifter.

A Grant GT steering wheel and Auto Meter gauges were also utilized. The cluster indicates 471 miles.

The custom Roush V8 uses a Dart aluminum block, Wiseco forged pistons, an Eagle crankshaft and connecting rods, Clevite bearings, a COMP cams solid roller camshaft and lifters, and Trend pushrods along with AFR heads. The Holley HP-series carburetor is mounted on an Edelbrock Super Victor intake manifold. Stainless-steel headers are linked to a custom exhaust system, and the engine has fabricated aluminum valve covers. The engine is claimed to produce over 600 horsepower.

The Tremec T56 six-speed manual is linked to a Ford 9″ rear end with a Detroit Truetrac differential and 4.11 gears.
